description.text:
To help stay up-to-date, hereâ€™s a truly non-digital desk calendar.  
When printing, our bot is live to the web at www.justin.tv/bot14me2
Peace!

The two-color option, for those who can, is laid out for a MakerBOT Replicator with two .stl files. Each will need to be â€œmoved to platformâ€ and â€œcenteredâ€ to assure accurate registration relative to each other.  Make a .gcode file of each and then (for us, after closing and re-opening a clean run of ReplicatorG) on the â€œGcodeâ€ pull down, select â€œmerge .stl for dual extrusionâ€.  Pick one of your 2color .gcodes for left and the other for right, give the resultant merged dual .gcode a name and select â€œmergeâ€. 
The single-color option is all on one .stl file.
Enjoy!

title: Parametric Lego Mindstorms NXT Ball Bearing

description.text:
Parametric Lego Mindstorms NXT Ball Bearing. The Mindstorms NXT kit contains several big balls. With aid of this bearing, the robot can turn easily in all directions. The most important parameters are:
  • the "offset": an offset of "0.0" creates exactly half a sphere. A positive offset will make the sphere go further around the ball. An offset of "8.0" will give a good result.
  • the "ri3": this value should be slightly more than the radius of ball, so that the ball turns freely inside the bearing.
    • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K8aD5dkZ6q4&feature=youtu.be Remark:
    An improved version of this design can be found at:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:285153

title: Open Source Camera Holder for Manfrotto Clamp

description.text:
I needed a clamp for my motion capture camera's and I didnt want to pay 20$ for 20, so I decided to make them, my fist attempt was wooden, they worked for a while but over time I realized that they would warp and the cameras would move - which is not good for calibration. Then I decided to learn solidworks and design a new holder and I came up with this new one, it works great and this saved me $400 from having to buy them on eBay! I've included the "Final Camera Holder" file and the "Single Camera Holder" File and the Camera Post.
You need the Final Camera Holder and Post, the Single Camera Holder is for misprints so you don't have to print 2 at a time.

Your going to need these parts to complete the unit: (1) 2" (5/16) NON galvanized carriage bolt
(1) 1/4" 20 x 3/4 Thumscrew
(1) 5/16 Butterfly Nut You can get any length you want of the above but that is what I use and it fits nicely. I've included the "Final Camera Holder" file and the "Single Camera Holder" File and the Camera Post.
You need the Final Camera Holder and Post, the Single Camera Holder is for misprints so you don't have to print 2 at a time. First, connect both halves together, Second, insert the carriage bold and nut through the holes and make sure the carriage bolt fits into the square indenture, making sure the the overhang in on the rightmost part of the unit AWAY from the butterfly nut as shown in the picture. Third, insert the post into the bottom base using the smaller end of the post which is the BASE of the created post of the markerbot. The base is just a bit smaller due to it being created first, this defect allows the tip to be insert while the other end will not. Push the piece all the way though until it hits the OPENING of the second whole but do not push it through the second whole - just make it flush with the whole opening. Fourth, the tricky part, insert the thumbscrew in the top hole, this will not fit at all; using a gentle twist and pushing motion, the screw will eventually screw itself into the plastic creating its OWN grooves within the hole, creating a nice solid and tight fit. It would most likely not be necessary to have a thumbscrew for the bottom, but you can if you want to.

comments.text: Why does this camera need attaching to a lightpost mount?

author: OrcaPus

description.text:
Keep your table tops free of water damage from your cold drinks!  OR make one for each of your kids so that they can keep track of your cup throughout the day.
The .stl file has a place to add a name (if you have software that allows you to edit an .stl).  If you canâ€™t edit .stl files you can find the original at TinkerCAD.com  or you can print this as is and paint the name on the coaster.

1) Print. I used:
  • 1 skin
  • .27 layer
  • 10% fill
  • not accelerated
    2) Add felt pads to the bottom
    • At the end of the day I always have a dishwasher full of kid cups. These coasters have helped solve that problem. I made one for each of my kids. Now they get a new cup in the morning and keep it on the coaster all day. The process isn't perfect (kids take a lot of reminding) but is has helped.

comments.text: If it's such a problem to remember to use the coaster why not just make a circle that fits around the cup with the child's name on it?

title: Kossel Mini FSR Mount for 180mm glass

description.text:
Using force sensing resistors for bed leveling which removes the problem of recalibrating the printer every time after moving it. These are made for 180mm diameter glass with adjustment of a few mm in either direction. Original idea by Johann C. Rocholl who is a reprap pioneer.
http://reprap.org/wiki/FSR

Infill 25% or more and normal printing speeds. Heated the tubes to get a exact fit on the parts.  
Hardware needed are M4x25 socket screws and some number 4 wood screws

title: Heavy Duty Lazy Susan for Full Body Scanning (Legacy Design)

description.header: This thing is now deprecated and replaced with my 2.0 version "Scan-O-Tron Turntable v.2.0 for Full Body 3D Scanning" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:729923 which uses a chain drive and wormgear motor to lock the turntable as the subject mounts and dismounts.
description.text:
A 3D scanning turntable capable of supporting the weight of a human being. Since discovering ReconstructMe, I've been looking for a suitable turntable setup for creating full body scans of people. Most of the plans out there are for tabletop photo or scanning setups that won't handle a lot of weight. Lo and behold, I found these plans http://cheesycam.com/motorized-lazy-susan-heavy-duty/, for using the
front wheel hub assembly from a car as the rotation bearing and an electric drill to power turning it. My implementation can be built for around $100. This device is the centerpiece of my Coney Island Scan-A-Rama Project- a next generation photo booth in which subjects are scanned and printed. Update 10/16/2012

I have added a 12volt 4RPM high torque rotisserie motor with a 3D printed pulley driving a bicycle inner tube belt drive. I just uploaded images of the motor (got it on ebay), the updated assembly, as well as source files for my pulley print, with slots for a set screw and nut.   
Update 7/21/2013

Added a new pulley in two parts that can be printed on a Replicator build platform, then glued afterwards. Drill afterwards to use a setscrew through a bolt in the slot against the flattened part of the motor shaft.   
Update 8/3/2013

I have also added a foot pedal to apply power to the turntable motor. However, I am seeking advice for a braking mechanism for the wheel when power is not applied. I was thinking a solenoid or something that could retract as power is on. I have safety concerns for the wheel spinning as people climb on or off the wheel. Any thoughts on this are appreciated.   
Update 2/6/2015

I added some images of the brake assembly. This will be the last update to this thing as this design is deprecated. I hope to post the designs for my 2.0 turntable design soon. The new design uses a worm gear motor and chain driving a sprocket to rotate the wheel, making for easier mounting and dismounting of the scanning subject.

See the Make Magazine build instructions here:
http://makezine.com/projects/guide-to-3d-printing-2014/heavy-duty-turntable/ Parts needed:
-Front Hub Assembly from car (~$30 on Ebay)
-2x 28" plywood circles (top plates)
-1x 12" plywood circle (Inner part for belt drive pulley)
-1x 14" plywood circle (outer part for belt drive pulley)
-1x 28" plywood square (base)
-10" plywood square
-some 2x4 and plywood scraps
-6x 3 1/2" x 3/8" carriage bolts
-3x 3"x 1/2" lag bolts
-Fender washers
-old bike tire tubes for the belt to power the turntable
-12 volt 4 RPM high torque rotisserie motor
-hose clamps
  • Foot Switch (such as http://www.harborfreight.com/power-maintained-foot-switch-96618.html)
    -Extension cord
    • Steps:
    1) Using a router or jigsaw, cut out the circles from a sheet of 3/4" plywood.
    2) Next, cut inner circles out of the center of both squares and the 12 and 14" circles. This gives a place for the center of the hub assembly to recess into so that it can be bolted onto the plywood.
    3) After placing the hub, mark the wood and drill holes for the bolts.
    4) Bolt the hub to the base. Add 2x4 blocks to the corners of the base as feet.
    5) Bolt the top turntable to the top of the hub. The order the circles stack is 14", 12", 28" 28". This creates a pulley to power turning the platform and a double layer of plywood on top for people to stand on.
    6) Mount the rotisserie motor with the printed gear on a 2x4. Put the bike tube around the pulley under the turntable, and stretch it around the pulley on the motor. Screw the 2x4 to the base so that the belt is stretched tight. Now get someone to stand on it, fire up ReconstructMe, and start scanning with the human highres setting!

It would stall, especially if the load on the table was off center.

Hi Everyone,

comments.text: Thanks @KingRahl, @fredini. I ended up making the table top 34" in diameter and it seems to hold 3 people well. I just have the 2 layers of 3/4" wood glued together. I did spring for some nicer wood. I suppose it would have been good to have used some screws across the 2 layers. If I were to do it again, that's one thing I'd change.
comments.author: digitalaudiotape

comments.text: I'd like to have at least 2 people on the platform. What size diameter do you think the table surface can be extended beyond 28" and still be safe? Thanks for posting this design online BTW
comments.author: digitalaudiotape

comments.text: Rahl is right, but as is, this design supports up to 3 adults.
comments.author: digitalaudiotape

comments.text: The weight the platform can handle is dependent on the load capacity of the wheel hub, the strength of the wood, and your own construction capabilities. The hub is the strongest point. You need to look at the wood. All the support is coming from the center of the hub. As the weight is applied on the outside diameter, stress is created toward the center like a fulcrum. To overcome this you can do one or both...
comments.author: digitalaudiotape

I have a 12v rotisserie motor from China but am wondering what kind of power supply to hook it up too, i.e how many watts will it need to turn up to 3 folk around?  Look forward to seeing your brake design too.

Jason,

I have added a brake pedal that applies pressure to the underside of the wheel as people climb on and off as well- need to update the project with this. comments.text: Based on my experience, I'd say the optimal time is a 20 second rotation of the wheel. A scan can be completed in about 3 revolutions, maybe 4 if its a complex subject. The new design is now posted and has several improvements: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:729923

comments.author: fredini

comments.text: Here is an idea, use the mcmaster style lazy susan bearing and mount high quality rollers or casters around the outside of the disk to keep it level and compensate for the small diameter of the McMaster bearing.  The drive motor could be housed inside the base.  Here are some screenshots from a rendering I just did of this idea.  I have not tried to build it yet.  The number of rollers would be based on their load rating.  The wheel on the motor would be sized to generate the desired RPM of the stage based on motor speed and inside circumference of surface the drive wheel bears on.  Foot petal or simple on off switch to control motor.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: I would consider this approach with a subsequent turntable, but my initial experiments with these bearings showed that they didn't do too well with uneven weight distribution. Using the bearing in the center and rollers on the sides is a better solution, but with a lot of weight on the rollers I just don't know how it would spin.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: Hi, I'm working on an update to the project and am looking for advice on a braking mechanism for the wheel when power is not applied to the motor. Any advice is appreciated!

A simple mount which holds the Bowden cable and your extruder. It "snaps" onto the top rails of a Prusa. I designed this so that I could use a Bowden extruder while still having my filament spools mounted to the top of the machine.  I mounted this to the front side of my Prusa but it could also be mounted in the other direction.
Print it out and snap it into place on the top rails of your Prusa. Optionally, secure it with zip ties. Then just snap the Bowden cable in and attach the extruder.

description.text: This fits right on the bolt holes on the front of The Replicator. This was seen in Episode 5 of Season 2 of MakerBot TV http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k815gaeElW8 Created by Todd Blatt

Just take out the two bolts on the left side of the front panel of The Replicator, slide this on, and bolt it back together.  The usual DualStrusion technique applies.
-Todd

I've always wanted to have a model of the starfury space fighter from the series Babylon 5. I purchased a resin kit back in the day, but it was warped. There are several starfury models here, but they either have too little detail, or the details are such that they don't print well. Also they were all too small. I want a big one!  
This model is 27 cm across and has all the detail I'm looking for. It printed comfortably in the relatively small build volume of my Afinia. Most of the parts print with only minimal support.  
I created this model using MODO and Mesh Fusion, using a reference model originally from Willian Vaughan.

All the parts are oriented as if they were assembled, so you have to change orientation for printing.

  • print

    • central body -- I oriented it nose up
    • two each: left gun and right gun

  • attach guns
    The guns fit into slots in the sides of the body. The upper pair need to be shaved or forced to get them in place. I use plastic epoxy, but any glue can work.

  • print & attach wings

    • upper left
    • lower left
    • upper right
    • lower right
      I rotated the wings so the trailing edge was flat along the build platform.

  • print & attach engine cowls matching each wing

  • print & attach thrusters

    • 4 x forward
    • 4 x rear
      I pointed the nozzles upwards. When attaching, align the flanges to the up-down and left-right axes.

  • print & attach struts
    You need 8, so print the strut_x4 twice. These attach to the rear thruster flanges along a 45-degree angle making an X.

  • print & attach fins
    • 4 x large
    • 4 x small
      These were hard to print because they are so thin. I had some better success printing the small one vertically inside a box. Go figure. They mate with the struts, the large ones pointing out, the small ones pointing in. I switched to superglue for these so I didn't have to hold them as long.

comments.text: I've got about half of the parts printed and they're coming together beautifully, but I'm having a mesh problem with the upper wings. Slicing in Cura 3.0.3 I get a chunk missing near the base for both sides.
comments.author: Toukejin

comments.text: I've uploaded WingUpper_2M which should have better geometry for slicing. You'll need to mirror it to print both sides. Let me know if this works for you.
comments.author: Toukejin

comments.text: That looks good, thanks.  I should be mostly assembled by the end of the day.

author: sclarkworking

title: All Hail the Mighty Clash of Clans bombers

description.text:
My son saw some video on YouTube where this kid made Clash of Clans characters out of different Lego pieces. Well, I took it a step further for my son.   
Made the bomb in Solidworks. The wick is printed separate because I am going to print the bomb in black for him and the fuse wick in glow in the dark filament. This one is printed in ABS just as a test print.   
There are two files, one with the fuse and one without. I was going to remove the one without but in case anyone wants it, I left it. The diameter for the fuse opening is 2mm.   
This is my first upload to Thingiverse.   
Revised:  
I added another file for the fuse alone. I realized that the file with both the bomb and the fuse could not be printed separate with Makerware. I also think printing it in ABS is way better because of the ABS being stronger than PLA.   
claimer: Son had to add the wall in the picture.

author: rmorales1259
